  • • Talus, S2, and S3:

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD

options.label: D
options.text: Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for age less than -3 SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition is defined by weight-for-height less than -3 SD, MUAC < 115 mm, or the presence of bilateral pedal edema, but not by weight-for-age less than -3 SD.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum. Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum. Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone:
  • • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Sphenoid bone:
  • • greater wing
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone:
  • • The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum:
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen):
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • • Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tumor size <4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast conservative surgery involves the removal of the primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, followed by adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes through a separate axillary incision.
  • ➤ Absolute contraindications for breast conservative surgery include pregnancy, persistently positive margins, multicentric lumps, diffuse microcalcification, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and inflammatory breast cancer.
  • ➤ Relative contraindications include active systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, a large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump), known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), multifocal disease, and prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.
  • ➤ Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

  • ➤ Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes
  • ➤ Treatment
  • ➤ Oxygen supplementation Move to a lower altitude Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.
  • ➤ Oxygen supplementation
  • ➤ Move to a lower altitude
  • ➤ Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  • ➤ Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

questions.text: Thiazide works on ________ in DCT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Na+Cl-Cotransporter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Thiazide diuretics act specifically on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na + Cl - ) cotransporter, which is responsible for the reabsorption of sodium and chloride from the lumen of the DCT into the cells. This inhibition leads to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in diuresis (increased urine production).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Na + K + 2Cl - Cotransporter : This cotransporter is located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not in the DCT. Therefore, thiazide diuretics do not act on this transporter.
  • • Option A. Na + K + 2Cl - Cotransporter
  • • Option B. ENaC Channels : Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are found in the collecting duct (CD), not the DCT. Thiazide diuretics do not affect these channels.
  • • Option B. ENaC Channels
  • • Option D. Na + H + Antiport : This antiport mechanism is not the target of thiazide diuretics. They do not act on this transport system in the DCT.
  • • Option D. Na + H + Antiport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na + Cl - cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)

Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient underwent a renal transplant following which he developed an infection that had owl eye inclusions. What is the likely cause of the finding? (NEET PG 2023)

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae , is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics. Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones. More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea. The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.
  • • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae , is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chancroid : Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi , has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.
  • • Option A. Chancroid
  • • Option B. Donovanosis : Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis , is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • • Option B. Donovanosis
  • • Option C. Syphilis : Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum , is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.
  • • Option C. Syphilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).
  • • Option B. Nasal packing:
  • • Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.
  • • Option C. Antibiotics:
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Name the material which is used for Lichtenstein mesh repair:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polypropylene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polypropylene mesh is the material of choice for Lichtenstein mesh repair due to its non-absorbable nature, providing long-term reinforcement for hernia repairs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Tolterodine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tolterodine is an appropriate treatment for overactive bladder, but caution is needed in dementia patients due to its anticholinergic properties, which can potentially worsen cognitive function. When selecting an anticholinergic drug for these patients, those with minimal CNS penetration, like trospium, would be preferable if available.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Iron overdose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BAL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: Concerning the mechanism of action of various antimicrobial drugs, which of the following statements is FALSE? (INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: A. Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Linezolid binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit, making the statement that it binds to the 30S subunit and inhibits protein synthesis false. The other drugs mentioned have their mechanisms correctly stated.

questions.text: The serosa is an important tissue layer that forms part of the wall of several parts of the gastrointestinal tract. In which of the following parts of the GI tract is the serosa layer absent? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The esophagus is unique in the GI tract as it lacks a serosa layer and instead has an adventitia.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The screening tests for UTI are as follows:
  • ➤ The screening tests for UTI are as follows:
  • ➤ Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine. Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result. Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.
  • ➤ Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • ➤ Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • ➤ Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • ➤ Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.
  • ➤ Quantitative Culture:
  • ➤ Standardized loop technique Pour plate method
  • ➤ Standardized loop technique
  • ➤ Pour plate method

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.
  • • Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period, presenting 5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Gonorrhea : Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.
  • • Option B. Gonorrhea
  • • Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.
  • • Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus aureus : Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ (REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)
  • ➤ (REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bortezomib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bortezomib , a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster due to its immunosuppressive properties. This highlights the importance of monitoring patients on such treatments for signs of viral reactivation
  • ➤ Bortezomib

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance . It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter . It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.
  • • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance . It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter .
  • • adder head sign/ cobra head
  • • appearance
  • • cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter
  • • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.
  • • Option B. Horse shoe kidney:
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis:
  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.
  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease , characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.
  • ➤ tibial tuberosity
  • ➤ Osgood-Schlatter disease

questions.text: A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? ( INICET Nov 2022) Low APGAR score. ADHD. Persistent pulmonary hypertension. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • a. Low APGAR score : SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.
  • • a. Low APGAR score
  • • b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.
  • • b. ADHD:
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension:
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)

questions.text: Which among the following is false? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L).

options.label: B

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows highest concentration in the serum? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ig-G

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Promethazine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions .
  • ➤ Risk factors
  • ➤ promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

questions.text: All of the following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in Refeeding Syndrome except: ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Refeeding syndrome occurs when nutrients are reintroduced to a severely malnourished patient, leading to metabolic and electrolyte disturbances. The reintroduction of carbohydrates causes an insulin surge, which drives electrolytes into cells, resulting in the following abnormalities:
  • • Hypokalemia : Potassium is driven into cells, lowering serum levels. Hypophosphatemia : Phosphate is used up in the production of ATP, lowering serum levels. Hypocalcemia : Increased cellular uptake of calcium can lower serum levels.
  • • Hypokalemia : Potassium is driven into cells, lowering serum levels.
  • • Hypokalemia
  • • Hypophosphatemia : Phosphate is used up in the production of ATP, lowering serum levels.
  • • Hypophosphatemia
  • • Hypocalcemia : Increased cellular uptake of calcium can lower serum levels.
  • • Hypocalcemia
  • • These hypoelectrolyte states are critical to monitor as they can lead to severe complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia : This is not seen in refeeding syndrome. Instead, refeeding syndrome typically results in hypokalemia due to the intracellular shift of potassium.
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia
  • • Option C. Hypocalcemia : Seen due to the cellular uptake of calcium.
  • • Option C. Hypocalcemia
  • • Option D. Hypophosphatemia : A hallmark of refeeding syndrome, driven by increased cellular utilization.
  • • Option D. Hypophosphatemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding syndrome is characterized by multiple hypoelectrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypocalcemia, but not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B giving negative feedback on Hypothalamus – pituitary axis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibin and Testosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibin and Testosterone are the hormones produced by Sertoli and Leydig cells, respectively, that provide negative feedback on the hypothalamus-pituitary axis in the male reproductive system.

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Synaptobrevin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medical students should understand that in tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin targets and affects synaptobrevin (VAMP), disrupting the SNARE complex and inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis. This knowledge is important for understanding the pathophysiology of tetanus.
  • ➤ The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.
  • ➤ Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10 th e/p 265
  • ➤ Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10 th e/p 265

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.
  • ➤ In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.
